This was probably one of the worst courses I have ever taken. I did not learn anything in this course. There was absolutely no structure and no proper explanation on the fundamentals of statistics. The instructor just talks about whatever he wants to talk about. He'll start class by asking "What do you want to know today?" except HE should be the one telling us what we should know. Absolute waste of my tuition dollars. Labs are also not explained well and I took nothing away from this class. This course needs serious improvement as most of the datasets posted for labs are incorrect or have multiple errors.

Strengths: 
- Simple concepts were explained more clearly in this course than Biostats I 
- Textbook in R was conducive for learning in lab

Weaknesses: 
- No real assessment before the final 
- Heavy weighting on the final (50%) 
-

Overall, I enjoyed applying course concepts in lab each week. This was an effective component of the course. I found the pace of the lectures to be too slow and this made me feel less engaged. I think that the course could be taught at a higher speed with more detail.
It was a fine overview of the linear and logistic regression. Disconnect between lab and lecture.
Weakness is exam didn't cover what we were applying in lab.

A waste of tuition dollars. Professor Zelterman is a very nice man, but I am unclear why I am paying thousands of dollars in tuition to teach myself a course. Dr. Zelterman comes to class unprepared and basically rambles for an hour and twenty minutes. He has no idea on important course logistics (e.g. thought we had an extra week of classes when we did not). It was honestly a very poor class and I am embarrassed that this is being offered at an institution like Yale.

This course was terribly unstructured and did not improve my knowledge of biostatistics. It felt as though we regressed in terms of difficultly and depth compared to biostatistics 1, which was fast-paced, challenging, and enriching. 

The expected outcome of the course were simply being able to interpret the right situations to use different statistical tests and how to interpret the equations of various regression models. Labs were simply copy and pasting code with a few areas that required actual critical thought. 

It is a shame that some departments are required to take this course, as it is not nearly up to par with other YSPH classes. I think that students in the past have not spoken up about the quality of this course because it is considered an "easy Honors".

I appreciated that this class was practical. There were weekly lab report that allowed us to apply our skills in R Studio. The code was often provided which put the focus on interpretation. I learned a lot from the labs. The lectures were a little less beneficial for me - there were no slides, just the professor writing under a projector. Sometimes it felt like the class lacked focus. It was hard to stay engaged.

Strengths: The lab reports are an excellent way to hone in the knowledge since they teach you how to interpret results and present them to the real world. They are also quite fun to do.
Weaknesses: Course is slightly unorganized and laidback, we were supposed to have a final project that never ended up happening, there was a lot of confusion regarding the final too since this was the first year this class offered a final.
This course introduces many statistical methods which is helpful.
Had a full picture of the statistics. But students are not very active in the class.
I thought it was extremely useful exercise completing the weekly lab assignments.

Overall it is a good course. The instructor raised many good questions for us to think critically, and also explained many concepts we learnt in last semester more clearly. However, I'm not sure why the students are not very engaged and responsive in class. Also, the labs are a little repetitive.
I think the course is very strong. I like how conceptual it is and not about trivial facts. It is practical. Writing a weekly lab report gives you the practice you need.

Strengths - balance between concepts and coding 
Weaknesses - Not structured
The professor should not say "Ni Hao" to the Chinese Nationals. This was a very offensive act and not conducive to the classroom environment.

The course was not what any of us expected coming from biostats 1. It is purely theoretical, which for a biostatistics course felt odd. I understand it is important to know the theory behind the statical analysis we perform, but I felt somewhat discouraged by the fact that we did not continue to gain tangible skills (e.g. coding). The lab reports allowed us to code a bit and think critically, and I truly found them to be amazing. As far as theory is concerned, the course did an amazing job at teaching it, but some more applied work would have been welcomed.
Good class; would rather prefer a final project rather than a final paper

This course has provided me foundational knowledge in regression methods that are needed for my work in epidemiology. While the same material is covered more in depth in other courses, this course gives students a more in-depth understanding of these methods. I put a lot of effort into the weekly lab reports and I enjoyed choosing a problem and a dataset to work on for these lab reports. The TFs are incredibly competent and and helpful in office hours. I would suggest that in the future, the teaching team should provide students bigger and more recent datasets. A lot of the datasets for the class are very old and not well configured. I would also suggest giving students a term project where they choose a dataset of their own, form a research question, identify a method, and write a report on it.

GREAT lesson
learn a lot about basic knowledge of biostatistics

Good exam 
Fair grading
Good TFs
Not the most linear lectures to follow
I liked the consistency of the course with the labs but I wanted more structure within the lecture.
I really liked the open lab format that emphasized interpretation instead of repeating technical tasks.
Dr. Zelterman is a great professor. However, I wish class was more challenging. It would have been better to have more coding examples in class and lab hours.
I really enjoyed the textbook and the labs.
Good class, great textbook
good

I did not feel like this course built on our biostatistics course from last fall which I would have actually appreciated. I also did not feel like the final exam as it was written had the capacity to adequately capture the knowledge we learned throughout the semester. It could have been helpful to be given access to the textbook prior to the start of the semester to better prepare for the topics covered.
The professor was very knowledgeable about the subject and provided great examples in class. The class time is a bit long though.

Very nice professor but does not have structured lectures at all. I stopped taking notes halfway through the semester because I couldn't follow what he's saying. I did not learn anything. So much of his R code is incorrect because he translated it from SAS. Students have so much difficulty trying to figure out how to IMPORT the dataset and some of the datasets do not even make any sense.

I think he took too long on straightforward concepts and didn't really go over R code. I also thought he was very tangential at times and because there were no pre-prepared notes, I found it very hard to follow him writing on a piece of paper.

Strengths: 

- Professor is very knowledgeable in the field, yet was able to explain basic concepts clearly and concisely  (I wish Professor Zelterman would have taught Biostats I, as the way he explained concepts clicked for me a lot more than they did last semester) 
- Professor is approachable and very helpful one-on-one


Room for improvement: 
- Structure of lectures/clear learning objectives
Somewhat unclear in his expectations.
Very bad.

The failure of this course can be attributed to the instructor. 

1) Dr. Zelterman did not have his TF's selected until the second week of class. This delayed signing up for labs and finalizing our schedules. 
2) In lectures he would often says "what do you guys want to talk about today?" and he would often go off on a tangent, finish, and pause, apparently trying to think of what to talk about next. The lack of lesson planning was very evident and created an unproductive and irritating learning environment. 
3) Dr. Zelterman intentionally withheld information about a supposed "Final Project". He instructed TF's to not answer any questions about it and said that he would only answer questions about it in class. When asked about the assignment, he would respond "well you should have come to class" to those who attended regularly. 
4) On the last day of class he was supposed to "collect" the final project. Instead, he FORGOT THAT IT WAS THE LAST DAY OF CLASS AND NEVER COLLECTED IT. Another example of his lack of commitment to this class. 

Ultimately, he was very bitter that the class had a low turn out and employed unfair tactics to try to incentivize attendance. If he wanted people to show up he should have 1) actually prepared a lecture or 2) made attendance mandatory. Instead he tried to manipulate students by withholding information about assignments, while simultaneously punishing students who actually showed up to class by not disclosing assignment information to them either.
Dr. Zelterman connects everything to real-life, and the application is extremely important, especially for public health students. For me personally, I would have liked slides just for focus.

Dr. Zelterman is truly a wonderful instructor who is very knowledgeable but also knows how to translate this knowledge into simple words for the students to understand. His style of teaching may be a bit slow sometimes, but he really wants to make sure that students understand what is going on. I truly believe that he should be teaching biostats 1 as well since it is important to gain foundational knowledge from a good instructor.
This class helped me understand a lot of concepts that I could not grasp due to the problems surrounding biostats 1 last semester. Dr. Zelterman is a great professor!
Teacher is patient and knowledgeable.
Dr. Zelterman has a very high level of expertise that he brings to every class lecture.

The instructor raised many good questions for us to think critically, and also explained many concepts we learnt in last semester more clearly.  However, I feel that the pace of the class is a little slow.
Great! He is very supportive and nice. He really knows his stuff and is very reasonable.
The professor should not say "Ni Hao" to the Chinese Nationals. This was a very offensive act and not conducive to the classroom environment.

He literally wrote the book on the subject, and his expertise was apparent. What he lacked, sometimes, was a clear plan. He didn't have TF's for the first two weeks of the course, would often open class by asking "what do you want to learn today?", and at the end of the semester didn't even know when the last day of classes was. I understand confusion with scheduling and what not, but I think the perceived lack of organization made students also never feel truly settled in the course or its expectations. Professor Zelterman was amazing, and taught us all beautifully. If he just added a bit more structure to the course, I think it would go a long way.
Good professor; engaging in class

I appreciate Dr. Zelterman's ways of communicating such complex material to a broader, non-biostatistics audience. Dr. Zelterman is very thorough in his lectures and asks interesting open-ended questions about statistical methods that prompt students to think about the material. I also appreciate that Dr. Zelterman focuses more on the practical applications of statistical concepts instead of expecting students to memorize the nitty gritty equations or theories. The class is taught mostly for non-biostatistics students, so these are reasonable expectations.
He's really excellent and know biostatistics really well. And he's very friendly.
Dr. Zelterman is very knowledgable and was able to lecture very well most days.
Great

He was awesome. He clearly knows statistics very well and has a lot of real-world experience and focused on teaching us the things (applications, when to use different techniques) that would actually be useful to us. Much of the material had been covered in the Biostats I course, but I didn't know what to do with it, and now I feel that not only can I use the Biostats I information but I can evaluate my models and whether they are appropriate. The class was not the most cooperative with asking questions and being engaged, but his lectures were easy to listen to, funny, and very educational nonetheless.
He is a great lecturer and I learned a lot from him! He was really helpful whenever I have questions and made class easier to understand for everyone in class.
Provide very comprehensive textbook, makes biostatistics easy to understand
good

The instructor was an ineffectual lecturer. He was not engaging in a productive way and he made comments that felt problematic more than once. He also almost verbatim lectured using his textbook as a script which did very little for my learning.
Very kind and supportive
ABSOLUTELY NOT. It's required for CDE students so there's no way to get out of this, but this course was an absolute waste of time and money.

This course focused on linear models (linear regression, logistic regression, poisson regression, cox proportional hazards regression, etc.). The course is very application-driven with little emphasis on mathematics/calculations. I wasn't very satisfied with the course overall, so I would not recommend it to another student. I thought that pace of the course was too slow and that I didn't gain as much as I wanted to. I would have liked to be challenged more. In other courses (epidemiology), topics related to biostatistics have come up and we haven't covered them (more about study designs, sampling, power, etc). I think that the curriculum across biostatistics/epidemiology should be more integrated to ensure students are learning what they need to (no gaps in the curriculum) and that courses reinforce topics, but have less overlap. There were points in the semester when the same topics were being covered in three different courses.
Learn more applications in R.
DO NOT TAKE!

Dr. Zelterman's teaching style is unacceptable and this class needs a new instructor and to be restructured. It is not nearly on par with the level of biostatistics that we should be learning in a Master's program. Truly a waste of time for students and resources of YSPH to conduct the course in its current state.

I do recommend this course because you learn about the main statistical tests, how to run them in R Studio, and how to analyze output. It's practical with a strong focus on interpretation. The lectures weren't the most engaging. Dr. Zelterman is engaging himself but it was hard to stay focused when it felt like we didn't have a clear outline/focus.
The course is laidback and the final is open-book. I would definitely recommend it to another student.
Yes I would recommend this course because students can practice their analytical skills in this course.
Fun course to put statistic methods into real world analysis!
I would summarize this course as a strong introduction to both R and biostats, potentially in a stronger manner than Biostats I.
Important extension from Biostats I. Learning to put regression models into context.

Course combining R skills with stats skills to complete data analyses. Recommend if willing to put time in outside of the class to learn more in depth, but class is unorganized and doesn't reinforce strong stats skills.
The professor should not say "Ni Hao" to the Chinese Nationals. This was very offensive and not conducive to the classroom environment.

The course is a 90% theoretical, 10% applied biostatistics course. It takes a deep dive through regression models, tests of independence, etc., and you'll leave with a sound understudying of any tests you might perform or read about in public health settings/studies. I would recommend the course if you are looking to understand statistical theory, but maybe elsewhere if all you desire is coding practice, you will not find it here in massive amounts. Overall, it is a course I found enjoyable, important, and highly recommendable.

Overall, great course! I learned a lot and had a positive experience. While the course might seem stress-free for a lot of people, I would recommend putting a bit more effort than average if you want to learn about different statistical methods more in depth.

A very basic and useful course
Yes
I got a good understanding of biostats. WAY BETTER THAN BIOSTATS I.
An application of the basics that were learned in Biostats 1.
I would recommend this to any student, public health or not, interested in learning how to build and evaluate statistical models because it gave a lot of information in a clear, funny, useful way.
Yes, I recommend.
Read the textbook.
good

I would not recommend this course to other students at all. I did learn a lot from the textbook and would have benefitted more from just that textbook and the lab assignments than from also attending lecture and the summary from the TFs in lab.
A class that all Public Health students should take!
